thread.title: Retirement Weekly: Should you use ROBS to fund your startup?
thread.title_full: Retirement Weekly: Should you use ROBS to fund your startup?

title: Retirement Weekly: Should you use ROBS to fund your startup?
text:
Free Preview 
For full access, Log in or Subscribe Now and get 4 weeks free! 
More entrepreneurs are using the rollovers from their retirement accounts to start a business. In fact, more than 10,000 business startups and franchises have been financed by using the method “rollover as business startup,” or ROBS, since 2005. And more are likely to follow. But what exactly are ROBS? And who should and shouldn’t use them? 
In a recent article in the Journal of Financial Service Professionals, Kenn Tacchino, a professor at Widener University and MarketWatch RetireMentor, examined ROBS. Below are excerpts from that article in response to questions from Retirement Weekly. What is a ROBS? 
The “rollover as business startups” (ROBS) strategy uses a qualified retirement plan rollover to start a new business or buy a business franchise. ROBS pose some challenging financial planning issues. Some believe ROBS are a misused rollover destined to wreck retirement and others believe ROBS may be the fuel needed to help a person reach their dream of business ownership. Why are people using them? To continue reading, please subscribe. Already a Subscriber? Log in
